message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The murmur location and the phonocardiogram suggest congenital leaflet fusion, which can cause symptoms of chest pain and breathlessness during exercise. Metastatic valvular calcification and Viridans group streptococci infection do not usually cause a murmur in the 2nd right intercostal space. Sterile platelet thrombi formation is not a common cause of cardiac symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The phonocardiogram shows an early systolic murmur in the 2nd right intercostal space, which is characteristic of aortic stenosis. Among the options, only congenital leaflet fusion can lead to aortic stenosis. Metastatic valvular calcification can also lead to aortic stenosis, but there is no mention of any underlying illness or risk factors for this. Sterile platelet thrombi formation and viridans group streptococci infection are not known causes of aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The phonocardiogram shows a harsh ejection systolic murmur, which is most commonly caused by congenital leaflet fusion (also known as Bicuspid Aortic Valve). Metastatic valvular calcification usually occurs in the elderly, and sterile platelet thrombi formation and Viridans group streptococci infection would not cause a murmur in this location.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The phonocardiogram shows an ejection click and a systolic murmur, which suggests mitral valve prolapse. This is most commonly caused by congenital leaflet fusion, making option (B) the most likely underlying cause of the patient's symptoms. Metastatic valvular calcification and viridans group streptococci infection can also cause murmurs, but they do not fit the presentation as well as mitral valve prolapse. Sterile platelet thrombi formation is not a known cause of mitral valve prolapse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The phonocardiogram shows a systolic ejection murmur in the 2nd right intercostal space, which is consistent with aortic stenosis. Among the options, only congenital leaflet fusion can cause aortic stenosis. Metastatic valvular calcification is a more common cause in older patients with cardiovascular risk factors. Sterile platelet thrombi formation and Viridans group streptococci infection are not known causes of aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The murmurs heard in the 2nd right intercostal space suggest aortic stenosis. Among the options, only congenital leaflet fusion can cause aortic stenosis. Metastatic valvular calcification is seen in patients with chronic kidney disease or end-stage liver disease. Sterile platelet thrombi formation may occur in patients with antiphospholipid syndrome, and Viridans group streptococci infection can lead to infective endocarditis, but neither matches the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The phonocardiogram shows an early systolic click and a late systolic murmur, which is characteristic of mitral valve prolapse (MVP), caused by congenital leaflet fusion. Metastatic valvular calcification usually presents with a murmur in the mitral area, not the 2nd intercostal space. Sterile platelet thrombi formation and viridans group streptococci infection are not associated with MVP.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The phonocardiogram shows a harsh systolic murmur, which is consistent with aortic stenosis. Among the options, only congenital leaflet fusion can cause aortic stenosis. Metastatic valvular calcification occurs in elderly patients with a history of atherosclerosis. Sterile platelet thrombi formation and Viridans group streptococci infection are not related to aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The phonocardiogram shows a harsh, crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard best at the second right intercostal space, which suggests congenital leaflet fusion, also called bicuspid aortic valve. This condition can cause aortic valve stenosis, leading to chest pain and breathlessness during exercise. None of the other options are associated with this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The phonocardiogram shows a crescendo-decrescendo murmur, which is consistent with aortic stenosis. Among the options, only congenital leaflet fusion can cause aortic stenosis. Metastatic valvular calcification is a complication of aortic stenosis, but not the underlying cause. Sterile platelet thrombi formation and viridans group streptococci infection are not associated with aortic stenosis.
